text:
Hi friends I am Niharika and welcome back
to a new lesson. In today’s lesson we are

gonna look at Adjectives comparing equal quantities.
Now in English, we do compare. We compare

things, we compare people. But what exactly
are the phrases that we use, when we tend

to compare equal things? Well, that’s what
we are gonna learn in today’s lesson. There’s

a certain pattern that we follow in English
in order to compare equal things. Now it can

be equal things or just about the same. And
what is that pattern, let’s have a look?

It’s the word “as” followed by the adjective
indicating quantity and then followed by the

noun that you’re comparing and then followed
by the word “as” again. So let’s go

through this again, it’s as plus adjective
indicating quantity followed by the noun and

then followed by the word “as” again.
Now in certain cases it’s okay to skip the

noun especially when you know that what exactly
are you talking about, it’s okay to let

go that noun. We will understand this better
in the examples and also another thing that

you really need to keep in mind is the type
of adjective that you use indicating quantity,

always depends on the noun that you’re comparing,
whether that noun is countable or whether

that noun is uncountable. So countable nouns
are the nouns that you can count, whereas

uncountable are the nouns that you really
can’t count on your fingers. So let’s

get started with some examples using or comparing
countable nouns. Now the phrases or the adjectives

that you would use to compare countable nouns
are, As many as 
or another one is As few as, so now let’s

go through the examples here. The first one.
They have as many children as we do, so here

we are comparing equal number of children,
maybe we have three children and guess what

even they have three children. So we are comparing
equal quantities and to do so we are following

this pattern here, so they have as, the word
as followed by the adjective many, that indicates

quantity and then followed by the noun and
again followed by the word as, so they have

as many children as we do. Another example
here, John has as few books as Jane, so again

you can count the number of books that you
have. Now probably here John counted the number

of books that he has, so when he counted,
he had like just eight books, whereas Jane

had nine books. So though they are not exactly
equal number of books, but they are kind of

same. He just has eight books and she has
nine books, so it’s almost the same. Again

you are comparing almost the same number of
books here, And how do you do that? By using

the same format, which is John has, the word
as, few is the adjective indicating quantity

followed by the noun and then followed by
the word as again, so John has as few books

as Jane. Let’s have a look at the third
example here, They have as many customers

as we do, so we are a big company and we have
a lot of customers. We can count the number

of customers or clients that we have, But
guess what even our competitors, even they

have equal number of customers that we do,
so again we are comparing equal quantities.

So what phrase do we use? They have as many
as your adjective indicating quantity, customers

is your noun and then followed by the word
as. Last example for you is, I have three

sisters. Maybe I’m talking about the number
of sisters that i have, i have three sisters,

that’s as many as you have, so if you observe
here, i have three sisters. So we are having

a discussion about the number of sisters that
we have, but if you look at the sentence here,

that’s as is as, many is your adjective
indicating quantity. And then where’s the

noun? Oh! You skipped the noun. You just end
it with the word as, why did we skip the noun?

Well, the reason because, we know what we
are talking about, so it’s not necessary

that I’m gonna say, Oh! I have three sisters
that’s as many sisters that you have, not

necessary , we know that we are talking about
sisters, so it’s okay to skip the noun,

so that’s exactly the reason, why we are
just using the phrase as many as you have.

So always remember when we are comparing nouns
and if its countable nouns then we would use,

as many as or as few as. And now let’s have
a look at some examples using or comparing

uncountable nouns. So we have certain examples
here that would help you to understand comparing

uncountable nouns. Now remember the adjectives
or the phrases that we end up using to compare

uncountable nouns are, As much as and the
other one is As little as. So uncountable

nouns are the nouns that you really can’t
count, so let’s have a look at the examples

here, John eats as much food as Peter, so
we are using the same formula to compare equal

quantities, so John eats, the word as is much
adjective indicating quantity, food is your

noun and then you end it with the word as,
so John eats as much food as Peter. Well you

can’t really count food, can you? Oh! This
is one, this is two, this is three, we can’t

do that, food is uncountable, so we are using
the adjective much. Next one, she has as little

patience as me. Oh! Yes i do not have any
patience, i lose out completely. So here i

am comparing with her of course the amount
of patience that we have, so patience, you

can’t really count patience. So patience
is an uncountable noun and we would use the

same format, she has as middle as the adjective
indicating quantity, patience is your noun

and then you end it with the word as. Next
one they have got as little water as we do,

so probably we have very little water in our
house. And guess what; even she has almost

the same amount of water that we have left
with, so again we are comparing almost the

same quantity. They have got as little is
your adjective, water is your noun and then

you end with the word as. And then the last
one, Well, I’m not hungry; maybe i have

eaten too much, so I’m not hungry. I have
had as much as she has, so probably, she’s

had a lot of food and she informed this to
her mom, look I’m not hungry, i ate too

much. Now i am comparing myself to her because
even i ate the same amount of food that she

did, so here I’m saying, I’m not hungry.
I have had as much is the adjective and then

you end it with the word as, where’s the
noun? Isn’t it obvious that we are talking

about food? So here as i mentioned again,
it’s okay to skip the noun especially when

you know what exactly you are talking about,
it’s like inevitable. So I’m not hungry,

i have had as much as she has had, so this
is the way we will end up using or comparing

countable or non-countable nouns. Now if you
have understood this then go ahead take a

test and let me know how much did you score.
I’ll be back with a new lesson. Till then you take care
